support_summary: In response to DNA damage, TDP-43 is recruited to double-strand break sites and directly interacts with the DNA-dependent protein kinase catalytic subunit (DNA-PKcs, or PRKDC) as part of the non-homologous end joining (NHEJ) repair pathway.

functions.cellular_process: TDP-43 is a key component of the non-homologous end joining (NHEJ) pathway, the primary mechanism for repairing DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs) in post-mitotic neurons. Upon DNA damage, TDP-43 is recruited to DSB sites where it interacts with core NHEJ factors, including the DNA-dependent protein kinase catalytic subunit (DNA-PKcs, or PRKDC).
functions.effect_description: TDP-43's interaction with PRKDC is essential for the proper execution of non-homologous end joining (NHEJ), and its loss impairs the repair of DNA double-strand breaks.
biological_consequence: DNA double-strand break (DSB) occurs → TDP-43 is recruited to DSB site → TDP-43 interacts with PRKDC (DNA-PKcs) & other NHEJ factors → TDP-43 scaffolds XRCC4-Ligase 4 complex → Successful Non-Homologous End Joining (NHEJ) repair → Maintenance of genomic integrity.
Loss of nuclear TDP-43 → Impaired recruitment of XRCC4-Ligase 4 to DSBs → Defective Non-Homologous End Joining (NHEJ) → Accumulation of DNA damage → Neuronal apoptosis & genomic instability.
specific_effects: TDP-43 is rapidly recruited to sites of DSBs and interacts with NHEJ factors including Ku proteins and DNA-PKcs (PRKDC).
TDP-43 acts as a scaffold to recruit the XRCC4-DNA ligase 4 complex to DSB sites, a critical final step in NHEJ.
Depletion of nuclear TDP-43 impairs NHEJ, leading to persistent accumulation of DNA damage in neurons and in ALS patient spinal cords.

evidence.paper_title: Loss of TDP-43 function contributes to genomic instability in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
